author: Staff Reporter
text:
Atsuko Baba (right), first lady of the Consulate General of Japan, at the Ikebana exhibition on Wednesday —photo: m. Vedhan

After the Japanese language and Origami, it is the turn of Ikebana, the Japanese art of flower arrangement, to become the rage in the city.

Having arranged agapanthus, lilies and chrysanthmum flowers upright, Masoko Maryama, one of the students of The Ohara School of Ikebana Study Group in Chennai, who displayed their works at an exhibition in Chennai, talked about why she loves the city.

“I came here in 2012 as my husband was posted here and ever since, it has been an amazing experience. What I could not do and find time for in Japan, I am glad I could learn here,” she said.

Cherry Venkatesan, who started the school after she was inspired by her teacher Norico Koyabachi, said she has had over one hundred students in the last 11 years.

Flowers from Ooty

“I get flowers from Ooty and Bengaluru for these classes. The art of cutting it does the magic in Ikebana,” she said. The exhibition has 25 different styles of flower arrangement displayed by nine students of Ms. Venkatesan.

Atsuko Baba, the first lady of the consulate general of Japan, inaugurated the Ikebana exhibition.

Flowers are brought from Ooty and Bengaluru for the classes
title: Japanese flower arrangement, Ikebana, the new rage
